These process changes are allowable without the need of MOC forms as long as they are within the range of safe operating limits specified in the Operating Procedure.

  In order to maintain the integrity of an operating process and allow for those instances where Emergency actions are required, an operator must have the flexibility to take immediate actions to make necessary process changes to process operating conditions. These Emergency process changes are reserved for those situations that are legitimately urgent and require some type of immediate action to stabilize and bring a potentially catastrophic situation under control. These actions will be allowable without the need of MOC forms as long as they are within the range of safe operating limits specified in the Emergency Operating Procedure.

Incident Investigation

  Incident investigation is the process of identifying causes of incidents and implementing steps to prevent similar events from occurring. The intent of an incident investigation is for employers/employees to learn from past experiences and thus avoid repeating past mistakes. 
This procedure is designed to meet the strict criteria of OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM), and EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP).

  The Incident Investigation process should be applied to all Accidents, Incidents, Incidents that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release, and Near Misses that occur. OSHA N AC definitions of these conditions are as follows:
¿	Incident: An unplanned, undesired event that adversely affects completion of a task.
¿	Catastrophic Release: An uncontrolled emission, fire or explosion involving one or more highly hazardous substances or explosives that presents imminent and substantial endangerment to the health of the employees, the public health or the environment.  The term includes events that occur within a building or other structure that contains the substance or explosive.
¿	Accident: An undesired event that results in personal injury or property damage.
¿	Near Miss: An incident where no property was damaged and no personal injury sustained, but where, given a slight shift in time or position, damage and/or injury easily could have occurred. Note: a Near Miss does not necessarily require a release of process fluids. Any incident that could have reasonably resulted in a catastrophic release under differ

The Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Lightning Dock Geothermal (LDG) Power Plant

  The LDG Power Plant is located at 15 Greenhouse Drive, Animas New Mexico in the county of Hidalgo near the town of Animas New Mexico. The facility is committed to being a responsible member of the nearby communities. Site policy dictates that the LDG Power Plant continuously identify methods to identify and reduce the risk to the community and environment through implementation of inherently safe technologies and procedures. This commitment to safe and environmentally sound operations is documented in policies and safety procedures at the facility which are available to all employees who are trained to these policies and safety procedures.
 
Description of the Lightning Dock Geothermal Power Plant and the Regulated Substance Used.

  The power plant uses heat from geothermal brine at approximately 310 degrees Fahrenheit to heat, through a non-contact heat exchange process, a single turbine isobutane process that converts the geothermal heat to electric power for sale to PNM, through transmission to Columbus Electric Cooperative, the local energy cooperative for the local communities' electric power needs. The isobutane used in the closed loop (recirculated/recycled) power generation process is the only regulated substance at the site. The facility can have on site up to approximately 57,200 gallons of isobutane being used in the process or being stored. It is expected that, due to fugitive emission losses, no more than one truck of approximately 4,200 gallons of makeup isobutane will be required per year and, in fact, continuous monitoring of leakages and proper maintenance will in all eventuality reduce fugitive emission losses and need to replenish significantly. When isobutane is delivered to the site it will be off loaded at a designated isobutane storage area and under well qualified employees and approved safe operating procedures.

The power generation process (ORC Turbogenerator) consists of heat exchangers (two preheaters and one evaporator) which absorb heat from the geothermal brine in order to boil and convert the iso butane into its vapor phase. The vaporized iso butane is then directed to a turbine specially designed to convert thermal energy in the iso butane to rotational mechanical energy. The turbine which is directly coupled to a generator, in turn, rotates the generator leading to the generation of electrical power. Iso butane from the turbine is directed through a regenerator and then to the air cooled condensers that complete the condensing of iso butane back to its liquid phase. From the condensers isobutane falls to the suction of feed pumps which pressurize the iso butane and direct the iso butane through the regenerator, a non-contact heat exchange process, to absorb heat from the iso butane moving from the turbine outlet to the condensers. From the regenerator the pressurized isobutane is once again directed to the two preheaters and evaporator.

The Worst Case Release Scenario and the Alternative Release Scenario.

  The Worst Case Release Scenario evaluated was that of a ruptured isobutane tank leading to a boiling liquid expanding vapor explosion (BLEVE) condition using 300,872 pounds of isobutane. The maximum distance to an over pressure of 1 psi is 0.5 miles (0.9 kilometers). The EPA's RMP Off site Consequence Analysis Guidelines for Worst-Case Scenario were calculated using RMP*Comp. Although there are numerous installed control measures that, in an actual event, would mitigate the release, no credit for mitigation measures was taken into account for this scenario.

  The Alternate Case Release Scenario evaluated based on the 1 pipe from the regenerator to the feed pump suction being hit, ruptured, subsequent hot liquefied iso butane leaking, and an ensuing vapor cloud explosion event that lasts for 20 minutes before any mitigating efforts can take effect. Pre Start Up Safety Review (PSSR)

  The Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) Program was developed to ensure completeness, operability and safety of all new or modified equipment, systems and subsystems; to assure that appropriate safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place; and to verify that a process hazard analysis has been performed.

  The PSSR includes the use of construction walk down checklists for mechanical, electrical and control systems, construction document audits, the verification of procedure development, performance of a PHA and MOC, verification of safety, operation and maintenance training and the documentation and correction of deficiencies and the confirmation of completion.

Mechanical Integrity Program

  To assure the continued integrity of process equipment and that all process equipment is designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to minimize the risk of process releases.

  Identify and categorize all process equipment and instrumentation.

  Development of written maintenance procedures and a quality assurance program.  

  Training for process maintenance activities, inspection and testing, and correction of deficiencies in equipment that is outside acceptable limits as defined by the process safety information. 

  This procedure is to be managed in accordance with SSP-1 - Program Management Plan and Document Control.


Management of Change (MOC) Program

  The intent of this procedure is to require management of all modifications to equipment, structures, buildings, procedures, raw materials and processing conditions other than replacement in kind by identifying and reviewing them prior to implementation of the change. Minimum requirements for management of change include: establishing written procedures to manage change; addressing the technical basis, impact on safety and health, modification to operating procedures, necessary time period, and authorizations required; informing and training employees and contractors affected; and updating process safety information and operating procedures or practices.

  The following is a list of examples where a MOC procedure is necessary:

    New projects that involve tie-ins, equipment additions or modifications, increase throughput or the use of a different raw material or additives.

    Significant changes in operating conditions, including pressures, temperatur

es, flow rates or process conditions outside the established ranges set for the process and mechanical design.

   Changes in alarms, instrumentation and control schemes.

   Changes to the process equipment that cause changes in the facilities pressure relief requirements.

   Bypass around equipment normally in service or running without equipment normally in service.

   Changes in operating procedures, including procedures for start-up, normal shutdown and emergency shutdown.

   Temporary connections, utilities, electrical, process, temporary repairs, pipe clamps. Etc.

   Replacement of components that are not in kind including gaskets, valves, bolts, etc. A MOC is not required for components which satisfy the in use/approved design specifications.

   Replacement of equipment with equipment of different design specifications, a change of manufacturer does not require an MOC if the specifications for the new equipment are the same as the one removed.

  This procedure shall be maintained to ensure it satisfies OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard 29 CFR, Part 1910; and EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) Standard 40 CFR, Part 68 confirmations that:

  The technical basis for change is appropriate.

  Industrial safety, health and environmental impacts of a change are understood.

  Procedures are modified as appropriate for change.

  Training is held as appropriate for change.

  Preventive Maintenance/Mechanical Integrity program is modified as appropriate for change.

  Determination of PSSR requirements as appropriate for change.

  Determination of the time necessary to make the proposed change.

  Permissible time period is established for temporary changes.

  Appropriate personnel authorize a change.

  The Process Safety Information (PSI) is updated as appropriate for change.

Accidental Release Prevention Program

  The accidental release program developed for the Lightning Dock Geothermal Power Plant is a formal program implemented to satisfy the requirements of the Occupational Safety and Health Admiration's (OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) and the United States Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) Risk Management Program (RMP) requirements. Additionally, it is the belief of Lightning Dock Geothermal management that this management program also lead to a more efficient and profitable operation.
The Process Safety Management program consists of thirteen program elements which comprise:

	PSM Program Management and Document Control
	Facility and Substance Information and Safety Information (PSI)
	Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
	Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs)
	Training Programs
	Mechanical Integrity
	Management of Change (MOC) Program
	Pre Start Up Safety Review (PSSR)
	Verification of Compliance Audit
	Incident Investigation
	Employee Participation
	Contractor Safety Program
	Emergency Action Plan

The Plant Manager is responsible for ensuring the implementation and management of the PSM program, however, all employees and contractors before doing any work on site are required to know and understand specified elements of the PSM program before undertaking any work on site. All responsibilities and requirements are specified in the PSM program.

A brief description of each element follows.

PSM Program Management and Document Control 

  It is important that the Lightning Dock Geothermal Power Plant continues to review and amend, in a consistent manner, relevant procedures and other supporting documents. This is to ensure procedures are working properly and have been, and are being,

developed pursuant to regulatory requirements. Also of importance are the ready identification, accessibility and appropriate archival management of such documentation. Evidence of compliance in this regard is a requirement of external authorities such as: 
It is also important that policies, procedures, process safety information and key materials are document controlled such that the relevant revision is readily identifiable by readers and users, as applicable at any specific time, especially for auditing and historical purposes.
The Plant Manager is responsible for an ongoing review all process safety information and procedures to make certain they are regularly updated in line with changing legislative and other requirements. All superseded process safety information and procedures are to be destroyed
An appropriate review process, incorporating employee consultation, is in place per the Employee Participation Program.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

  To establish a procedure for conducting a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for the Lightning Dock Geothermal Power Plant.  This procedure is required for compliance with OSHA Process Safety Management (OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119(e)).

  The purpose of the PHA is to:

	Define possible hazards associa

ted with the facilities process that includes isobutane. 

	Identification of any previous incidents, which had a likely potential for catastrophic consequences.

	Evaluate engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards.

	Determine the consequences of failures associated with engineering and administrative controls.

	Perform facility inspection and HAZOP study to determine the safety and health of employees.

	Establish a method of addressing team's findings and recommendations; assure the recommendations are resolved in a timely manner; document what actions are taken and a written schedule of when the actions are to be completed.

The PHA will be updated and revalidated every five years to ensure the study is consistent with the processes.

Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs)

The Lightning Dock Geothermal Power Plant Standard Operating Procedure Management is addressed in SSP-1 Program Management and Document Control and will be in accordance with the requirements of the following:  
	All up to date Standard Operating Procedures maintained in the SSP-4 folder on Box.com.
